greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of ways to write n=x+y (x>0, y>0) with 3x-2, 3x+2 and 2xy+1 all prime
comment: This has been verified for n up to 10^8. It implies that there are infinitely many cousin primes.

Zhi-Wei Sun also made some other similar conjectures, e.g., he conjectured that any integer n>17 can be written as x+y (x>0, y>0) with 2x-3, 2x+3 and 2xy+1 all prime, and each integer n>28 can be written as x+y (x>0, y>0) with 2x+1, 2y-1 and 2xy+1 all prime.
link: Zhi-Wei Sun, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Zhi-Wei Sun, Conjectures involving primes and quadratic forms, arXiv:1211.1588.
mathematica: apQ[{a_,b_}]:=AllTrue[{3a-2,3a+2,2a*b+1},PrimeQ]; Table[Count[Flatten[ Permutations/@ IntegerPartitions[n,{2}],1],_?(apQ[#]&)],{n,100}] (* The program uses the AllTrue function from Mathematica version 10 *) (* _Harvey P. Dale_, Jun 09 2018 *)
results.author: _Zhi-Wei Sun_, Dec 15 2012
